column4: Hi, I just reinstalled ubuntu.  I backed up my home directory, formatted my partition, reinstalled the distro, and overwrote the installed home directory with the one I had backed up.  Sound was working before I copied over my new home directory, but after I overwrote the old one, sound had stopped working.  Does anyone have any suggestions as to what user settings I could have that may have killed sound?
(sound hadn't been working under my previous install either)
Do you by chance have an ".asoundrc" file in that home directory?
Be sure you're still using "ALSA" as your sound driver--go the System > Prefs/Admin (don't remember which) > Sound
Hmm,  I have a number of choices, but none of them seem to work.  The two most promising seem to be HDA Intel (ALSA mixer) and Playback: ALSA PCM on front:0 (STAC92xx Analog)
I think you want the ALSA Mixer option because that will hopefully use "dmix", ALSA's way of allowing many apps to use the sound at one time.
OK, that was the default setting.  It looks like the card is detected and using the right driver and such, it's just that no sound comes out :(
Have you checked your sound levels? Be sure to set PCM volume <= 74% and then adjust master volume to see if you get anything. Make they aren't muted.

Well you could move all your .directories and .files out of your home directory, reboot, and Ubuntu/Gnome will go back to defaults. Then add them back one at a time to find which is causing the problems. This will prove also whether it really is a problem with something in your home directory.
that sounds like a good plan, I'll give that a shot
That's exactly what I was afraid of. That's why I figured we should try that...
You had sound working before you copied over your home directory?
Maybe another way of getting a clue would be to create a new user, log in as them, and see if the sound is a problem.
Yes, I was afraid that wasn't going to get sound working. Well good luck then with the reinstall. :)
Your welcome, and I would strongly encourage you to write down and keep track of any system changes you do. It will make troubleshooting things easier in the future.
